description.title: Cool It
description.description: A game about the greenhouse effect.

tutorial.atmosphere: The atmosphere is made up of a wide variety of gases such as oxygen, nitrogen, water vapor and many others. Without them, survival on earth would not be possible. Before playing, find out what influence the different gases have. This will help you later.
tutorial.light: Light comes to us in all forms from the sun. Visible light comes through the atmosphere and hits the earth. Observe what happens to the visible (here yellow) light when it hits an object.
tutorial.heat: Your mission: to make room for the excess heat radiation so that it can escape from the earth again. To do this, push the greenhouse gases out of the way. Why is the earth getting warmer?
tutorial.play: The bar at the top shows you the current temperature development. Try to stay in the middle range. If your average temperature or 3 buildings exceed or fall below the marked limit, the game is over.

order.globalWarmingFactorReal: Order the greenhouse gases by CO2 equivalent from the lowest to the highest
order.lifespan: Order the greenhouse gases by lifespan from the lowest to the highest
order.rationGreenhouse: Order the greenhouse gases by proportion of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere from the lowest to the highest

moleculeInfo.riseFactor: increase since the beginning of industrialization
moleculeInfo.none: Select an available molecule to show its information.

overview.title: overview
overview.description: The respiratory sphere is composed of the gases nitrogen, oxygen, argon and carbon dioxide. Light rays can pass through these gases unhindered. When a light ray hits the earth, it is absorbed by the surface and released as thermal radiation. Heat radiation is absorbed by the greenhouse gases and thus warms the atmosphere. Without these gases it would be very cold on Earth. The average temperature would be -18°C. Although the atmosphere consists of only 0.04% greenhouse gases, this is enough to warm the earth to a temperature that is comfortable for us. However, the more greenhouse gases, the warmer it gets. Gases and rays are colourless and very very small. So that you can see them, we have coloured them and enlarged them.
overview.chart-greenhouse2: composition of greenhouse gases in % without water vapor
overview.chart-greenhouse3: composition of greenhouse gases in % without water vapor and carbon dioxide

waterVapor.title: Water Vapor
waterVapor.pros: Up high in the atmosphere, it condenses back into liquid water and rains back down to Earth. The water we drink is part of this natural cycle.
waterVapor.cons: Water Vapor blocks heat from escaping the atmosphere, and warmer air holds more Water Vapor. Thus, as Earth heats up, more Water Vapor in the atmosphere traps more heat.

carbonDioxide.title: Carbon Dioxide
carbonDioxide.description: CO2 is the best-known greenhouse gas. It occurs in increased concentrations in our atmosphere, which continue to increase due to human influence. Natural sources are living organisms of all kinds and volcanoes.
carbonDioxide.pros: Carbon dioxide makes it possible for us to live on earth and reacts less strongly with heat radiation than other particles.
carbonDioxide.cons: However, the rapidly increasing concentration continues to warm the Earth's climate. In the last 100 years, the concentration has almost doubled. Carbon dioxide is also toxic to humans.

methane.title: Methane
methane.pros: Made of carbon and hydrogen, it is a natural gas released from wetlands, growing rice or raising cattle. Mining coal also releases natural methane pockets.
methane.cons: Methane traps a lot of heat. It is considered the second most important contributor to human-caused global warming of all the greenhouse gases.

nitrogenOxide.title: Nitrous Oxide
nitrogenOxide.pros: Nitrous Oxide is a natural part of Earth's nitrogen cycle. Bacteria in both soil and water create this gas.
nitrogenOxide.cons: Some factories, power plants and fertilizers release this gas as well. It is a powerful greenhouse gas which also damages the protective ozone layer.

ozone.title: Ozone
ozone.description: A useful shield against the sun's radiation!
ozone.pros: High up in the atmosphere, the ozone layer blocks the sun's radiation and thus protects us from those incredibly powerful rays.
ozone.cons: Closer to the ground it acts as a greenhouse gas and is usually formed by burning gas in cars or factories.

fluorinatedGases.title: Fluorinated Gases
fluorinatedGases.pros: Fluorinated Gases are usually used as a substitute to ozone-depleting substances and can be found in household appliances like refrigerators or similar. Some industries also heavily rely on these gases.
fluorinatedGases.cons: These gases do not appear naturally and are entirely synthetical. They are incredibly powerful greenhouse gases and some of them can linger in the atmosphere for a few millennia.

oxygen.title: Oxygen
oxygen.description: The one that keeps us alive.
oxygen.pros: While oxygen is not the most common gas in our atmosphere, it is the most important. Most life on Earth absorbs oxygen through breathing air which makes it an essential gas in Earth's atmosphere.
oxygen.cons: While its use in medicine is highly appreciated, oxygen is also used as combustion-sustaining element in a multitude of industries.

nitrogen.title: Nitrogen
nitrogen.description: The most common gas in Earth's atmosphere.
nitrogen.pros: Its close-to-inert nature and high availability make nitrogen a very useful gas for various applications. It is mostly used in food and chemical industries, in both its gaseous and liquid form.

argon.title: Argon
argon.pros: Argon is an inert gas and can thus be used across many different industries because of it. An example application would be the gas layer shielding the arc during arc welding.

helium.title: Helium
helium.pros: Helium is an inert gas which is of significant importance in many industries, mainly for its traits of being inert and having the lowest boiling point of any gas (-269°C).
helium.cons: Unfortunately, Helium is in high demand and short supply. On Earth it is mostly sourced from natural gas wells.

buildingInfo.none: Select an available building to show its information.

building01.title: Residential building
building01.description: Light colours and good thermal insulation ensure that the building stays cool in summer and warm in winter.

building02.title: Detached house
building02.description: Light colours and good thermal insulation ensure that the building stays cool in summer and warm in winter.

building03.title: Apartment block
building03.description: Light colours and good thermal insulation ensure that the building stays cool in summer and warm in winter.

building04.title: Residential building
building04.description: Dark colours and lots of glass ensure that the building is very warm in summer.

glassBuilding01.title: Office building
glassBuilding01.description: Glass heats up quickly and stores this heat poorly. The glass primarily releases the heat back into its surroundings. In addition, glass strongly reflects visible sunlight, which also heats up the immediate surroundings.

glassBuilding02.title: Office building
glassBuilding02.description: Glass heats up quickly and stores this heat poorly. The glass primarily releases the heat back into its surroundings. In addition, glass strongly reflects visible sunlight, which also heats up the immediate surroundings.

glassBuilding03.title: Office building
glassBuilding03.description: Glass heats up quickly and stores this heat poorly. The glass primarily releases the heat back into its surroundings. In addition, glass strongly reflects visible sunlight, which also heats up the immediate surroundings.

parkingLot01.title: Parking lot
parkingLot01.description: Asphalt heats up faster than vegetated ground and emits that heat back into its surroundings. Because of that, in summer it is way hotter on asphalted areas than on vegetated areas.

industry01.title: Warehouse tower
industry01.description: Dark colors absorb a lot of heat in the form of radiation. Metals heat up very quickly due to sunlight. Both heat up strongly and quickly and quickly release this heat back into the environment.

industry02.title: Factory
industry02.description: Dark colors absorb a lot of heat in the form of radiation. Metals heat up very quickly due to sunlight. Both heat up strongly and quickly and quickly release this heat back into the environment.

industry03.title: Factory
industry03.description: Dark colors absorb a lot of heat in the form of radiation. Metals heat up very quickly due to sunlight. Both heat up strongly and quickly and quickly release this heat back into the environment.

industry04.title: Factory
industry04.description: Light colours and good thermal insulation ensure that the building stays cool in summer and warm in winter.

trees01.title: Trees
trees01.description: Trees absorb CO2 and provide shade.

fertilizer.title: Fertilizer
fertilizer.description: Nitrogenous fertilizers in agriculture and livestock farming are the main sources of nitrous oxide emissions.

message.1: Heavy storms expected towards the end of this summer.
message.2: Austria now officially has less glaciers than the year before.
message.3: A vast wildfire spreads across a significant part of Styria.

message.1: A slight decrease in average temperature has been noticed this year. A cool breeze makes for a wonderful summer day.
message.2: Statistics show a decrease in floods during spring compared to last year.
message.3: Farmers report less pests on their crops. A better and greener harvest is expected.

message.1: More snow is expected to fall this winter. Wonderful news for ski enthusiasts!
message.2: The current list of endangered species has shrunk due to the stabilization of the global climate.
message.3: Some diseases have been reported to appear less often. A connection to the positive change in climate is not out of question!

message.1: Heat accumulation in big cities has been decreased significantly. The floor is NOT lava anymore!
message.2: Regular rainfall and less droughts helped immensely in re-vitalizing the ecosystem. Austria looks a lot greener again!
message.3: The glacial border has sunk again after years of rising. Natural water reserves seem to stabilize again.

veryEasy.title: very easy
veryEasy.description: At the time of the ice age, the global air temperature was -6°C. Under the conditions of a slight ice age of only -1°C, try to keep the temperature in the city in balance and prevent the earth from freezing by colliding greenhouse gases with the heat rays.

easy.title: easy
easy.description: At the beginning of the industrialisation there was no climate acquisition (global air temperature = 0°C). Under these conditions, try to keep the temperature in the city in balance. Ideally, you don't have to do much because the atmosphere is in balance. But the coincidence also resulted in temperature fluctuations at that time, so intervene carefully to balance these coincidences.

today.title: today
today.description: Since the beginning of industrialisation about 200 years ago, the global air temperature has risen by more than 1°C due to the increase in greenhouse gases. Try to keep the earth cool and prevent the red heat rays from colliding excessively with the greenhouse gases. But please don't prevent the greenhouse effect completely, because we don't want to freeze to death either.

hard.title: hard
hard.description: According to the Paris Climate Agreement, the global increase in air temperature should be limited to 2°C. Under these conditions, try to keep the earth cool and prevent the red heat rays from colliding excessively with the greenhouse gases. But please don't prevent the greenhouse effect altogether, because we don't want to freeze to death either.

statistic.level: How many times was which level played?
statistic.temperatureRise: How many times was which difficulty level played?
statistic.winPoints: How many times was how many points scored?
statistic.rating: How many times how many points were scored?
statistic.avatar: How often has which user played a level?
statistic.build: How often has which user created a level?
statistic.time: How many seconds did it take to finish the level?
